animalOfTheDay.name: termite
facts: Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

calendar.name: stingray
facts: Their stingers are modified scales and can deliver venom, but they only use them in self-defense.
Stingrays 'fly' through the water by flapping their pectoral fins like wings.
They use electroreceptors to detect the electrical signals of prey hidden in the sand.
Stingrays are closely related to sharks and have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.
They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.

calendar.name: termite
facts: They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

randomAnimals.name: stoat
facts: They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.

randomAnimals.name: badger
facts: Badgers are excellent diggers and can excavate tunnels faster than humans with shovels.
They have incredibly thick skin that can resist bee stings and snake bites.
Honey badgers are considered one of the most fearless animals in the world.
They have a symbiotic relationship with honeyguide birds in Africa.

randomAnimals.name: sable
facts: They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.
They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
